article.name: Learner Support: SecurityCoach Notifications
article.title: Learner Support: SecurityCoach Notifications
article.body:
If you’re reading this, your organization has deployed our SecurityCoach product. With SecurityCoach, you’ll receive SecurityTips to coach you about risky behavior. You’ll also receive training notifications for your security awareness training.

To learn more about the notifications you’ll receive and to see what they’ll look like, read about your organization’s delivery method below.

Microsoft Teams

If your organization uses Microsoft Teams, you’ll receive SecurityTips and training notifications in your Microsoft Teams account. To view what these messages look like, see the screenshots below.

SecurityTip:

Training Notification:

Slack

If your organization uses Slack, you’ll receive SecurityTips and training notifications in your Slack account. To view what these messages look like, see the screenshots below.

SecurityTip:

Training Notification:

Google Chat

If your organization uses Google Chat, you’ll receive SecurityTips and training notifications in your Google Chat account. To view what these messages look like, see the screenshots below.

SecurityTip:

Training Notification:

Email

If your organization uses email delivery, you’ll receive SecurityTips and training notifications in your work email account. To view what these messages look like, see the screenshots below.

SecurityTip:

Training Notification:

Feedback

If your organization requests feedback for SecurityTips, you’ll have the opportunity to provide that feedback at the end of your SecurityTip notification. When you provide feedback, your responses will go to your organization’s SecurityCoach admin team. To view what these feedback options look like, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Mark as Read: Select this button to confirm you have received the SecurityTip.
  2. Do you know why you received this message?: Select Yes or No to indicate if you know why you have received this SecurityTip.
  3. Share feedback or questions with your admin: Type in the text field to share any feedback or questions you may have about the SecurityTip.

Once you have provided your responses, click Submit at the bottom of the SecurityTip to ensure your responses are recorded.

images.context:
these messages look like, see the screenshots below.
SecurityTip:

images.alt:
This is an image of a system notification panel confirming training enrollment.

**UI Elements and Context:**

*   **Format:** A central white card with rounded corners, presented against a lighter background, typical of a modal or internal application message.
*   **Visual Indicators:** Located in the top-left margin is a primary orange/brown circular avatar/logo overlaid by a green checkmark icon, signifying a successful action or notification status.

**Text Content and Structure:**

*   **H1 Heading (Bold):** "You've been enrolled in training"
*   **Salutation:** "Dear [Recipient email address or name, blurred]"
*   **Enrollment Confirmation:** A statement confirming enrollment in the course: "You are now enrolled in Introduction to Data Protection."
*   **Mandatory Deadline:** The completion requirement is explicitly stated: "You must complete this training by March 26, 2024."
*   **Assignment Listing:** A preparatory sentence, "The assignments you've been enrolled in are displayed below:", precedes a bulleted list.
*   **Assignment Hyperlink:** A bullet point containing the training title in blue, hyperlink format: "Introduction to Data Protection".
*   **Training Link CTA:** A final instruction, "Please use this link to start your training:", is followed by the complete, blurred URL for access to the training module.

This image displays a security awareness notification within a dark-mode communication platform.

**UI Elements and Sender Context:**
*   **Sender:** The message is from an application labeled "KB4-SecurityAwareness APP," identified by a circular icon featuring an orange flow/recycling symbol.
*   **Timestamp:** The message was sent at "9:58 PM."
*   **Header:** The subject line is "High-Risk Activity Detected."

**Text Content (Notification Body):**
*   The personalized salutation is blurred ("Dear [Redacted Name]").
*   **Alert Message:** The text states, "You are receiving this message because high-risk activity was detected on your device. To ensure your organization's safety, please contact your administrator."
*   **Contextual Warning:** The text emphasizes the user's role in security, noting the goal is to "keep Accounting Group Accounts safe against cyberattacks!"

**Embedded Media/Attachment:**
*   A downloadable/previewable attachment is labeled "Real Time Coaching (155 KB)" with a file size indicator.
*   The preview image contains a security coaching module focused on data sharing risks.
    *   **Primary Text:** "Unauthorized communication with external organizations can be risky."
    *   **Actionable Advice:** "Review your organization’s policies and only share files and data with authorized stakeholders."
*   **Illustration:** The embedded graphic uses a split-tone isometric design (blue on the left, orange/yellow on the right) depicting two distinct buildings (representing organizations) connected by a dashed line path and a paper airplane, symbolizing unauthorized data flow or communication.

iew what these messages look like, see the screenshots below.
SecurityTip:

images.alt:
This image captures a notification message, likely within a chat or communication platform interface (indicated by the dark background and timestamp).

**Source and Context:**

*   **Sender:** An application named **"KB4-SecurityAwareness"**, labeled as an "APP" in the header. The app icon is an orange circle containing a white, counter-clockwise circular arrow.
*   **Timestamp:** The message was sent at **10:23 PM**.
*   **Header/Title:** The notification uses the headline **"You've been enrolled in training"**.

**Message Body (Text Content):**

1.  **Salutation:** "Dear [Blurred name/group, appears to read 'Accounting Group,'],"
2.  **Enrollment Confirmation:** "You are now enrolled in Introduction to Data Protection."
3.  **Deadline:** "You must complete this training by **April 04, 2024**."
4.  **Assignment Listing Introduction:** "The assignments you've been enrolled in are displayed below:"
5.  **Assignment Detail:** A bullet point listing one assignment:
    *   "- [Introduction to Data Protection](link)" (The link portion is a blue, underlined URL, heavily blurred).
6.  **Action Prompt:** "Please use this link to start your training:"
7.  **Training Link:** A second, distinct, blue, underlined URL is provided (heavily blurred).

**Visual Elements and Formatting:**

*   The message uses white or light gray text against a dark gray/black background.
*   Hyperlinks (the assignment link and the start training link) are indicated by blue text and underlining, characteristic of clickable UI elements.
*   The title is bolded or slightly larger than the body text.
*   The overall layout is typical of a plain text or rich text notification block.

This image is a screenshot of a security notification, likely an email or system alert, concerning a high-risk activity detection.

**UI Elements and Context:**

1.  **Notification Header:** The title of the alert, rendered in bold text, is **"High Risk Activity Detected"**.
2.  **Recipient Line:** A blurred greeting line reads "Dear [Recipient Group, partially obscured, appears to include 'Accounting Group']".
3.  **Body Text:** A standard warning paragraph explains the purpose of the message and provides context: "You are receiving this message because risky activity was detected on your device. Please review the information below to help avoid this activity in the future. Remember, you are our most important defense to keep Accounting Group Accounts safe against cyberattacks!"

**Embedded Educational Graphic:**

The primary content is a large, square graphic executed in a pixel art style (beige background, dark blue and maroon text/icons) designed for phishing awareness.

*   **Graphic Headline:** "STAY ON TOP OF YOUR GAME! WATCH FOR RED FLAGS." (Note: "RED FLAGS" is colored maroon for emphasis).
*   **Visual Motif:** A large, stylized, pixelated fish hook (maroon and dark blue) occupies the right half of the graphic, symbolizing phishing attempts.
*   **Key Security Indicators (Red Flags):** The graphic lists three indicators, each paired with a representative pixelated icon:
    1.  **Icon:** A paper clip. **Text:** "Strange attachments or links"
    2.  **Icon:** Two sets of double exclamation points. **Text:** "Sense of urgency"
    3.  **Icon:** The letters "acb" (indicating misspelling). **Text:** "Poor spelling"

images.alt:
An image displaying an email notification informing the recipient of mandatory training enrollment.

**Header/Sender Information:**
*   **Sender:** KnowBe4 SecurityCoach(US)
*   **Context Tag:** "App" (indicating an application notification)
*   **Timestamp:** "Now"
*   **Profile Icon:** A circular, orange-toned icon resembling a refresh or clockwise arrow.
*   **Subject Line (H1):** "You've been enrolled in training"

**Email Body Content:**
*   **Salutation:** "Dear \[Recipient Group, blurred],"
*   **Enrollment Notice:** "You are now enrolled in Introduction to Data Protection."
*   **Due Date Requirement:** "You must complete this training by April 04, 2024."
*   **Assignment Lead-in:** "The assignments you've been enrolled in are displayed below:"
*   **Assignment Details:** Blurred text representing training assignments or links.
*   **Call to Action:** "Please use this link to start your training:"
*   **Training Link:** A blurred URL displayed as a clickable blue hyperlink.

This image is a screenshot of an email interface displaying a security awareness notification from a sender identified as KnowbBe4.

**UI and Context:**
The email is contained within a standard client interface (likely webmail).
*   **Subject Line:** "High Risk Activity Detected."
*   **Sender:** KnowbBe4 `<do-not-reply@knowbe4.com>`.
*   **Timestamp:** 9:58 PM (10 minutes ago).

**Text Content (Email Body):**
The introductory text states: "You are receiving this message because risky activity was detected on your device. Please review the information below to help avoid this activity in the future. Remember, you are our most important defense to keep Accounting Group Accounts safe against cyberattacks!"

**Embedded Security Awareness Banner (Visual/Textual Content):**
The main content is a large graphic promoting cybersecurity awareness regarding phishing tactics.

1.  **Visual Elements:** A 3D illustration shows a yellow gift box emerging from a blue envelope. A light blue speech bubble above the gift contains the text "FREE GIFT!"
2.  **Primary Warning Text (Large Blue Font):** "Messages that mention free gifts are often scams!"
3.  **Supporting Explanation (Smaller Blue Font):**
    *   "Bad actors use gifts as incentives to trap users into compromising sensitive information."
    *   "Look out for alarming visuals and suspicious links!"

**Contextual Interpretation:** The message simulates a security incident alert to deliver a training module focused on identifying phishing scams that utilize promotional incentives ("free gifts"). The sender domain confirms this is a simulated attack (phishing test or training notification) originating from KnowBe4, a security awareness platform.
images.context:
iew what these messages look like, see the screenshots below.
SecurityTip:

images.alt:
The image displays an email notification interface confirming enrollment in security training.

**Email Structure and Content:**

1.  **Subject Line:** "You've been enrolled in training." The header also includes a gray "Inbox" label tag.
2.  **Sender Details:** The training platform, identified as "KnowBe4," sends the email from the address `<do-not-reply@training.knowbe4.com>`.
3.  **Campaign Details:** The body text confirms enrollment in the "Initial Training Campaign" and establishes a mandatory completion deadline: "You must complete this training by May 02, 2024."
4.  **Assignment Specification:** A specific assignment is listed as a blue, underlined hyperlink: "- 2023 Kevin Mitnick Security Awareness Training - 15 minutes."
5.  **Call to Action:** The final instruction is "Please use this link to start your training:" followed by a large, blurred section representing the training access URL.

This image displays an automated user notification regarding detected high-risk security activity.

**Header and Context:**
The notification is titled **"Risky Activity Detected."** The body text instructs the user that high-risk activity was detected on their device, advising them to **"contact your administrator"** and review internal policies.

**Educational Graphic:**
A central illustration features two structures (representing internal and external entities) and a paper airplane symbolizing data transfer. Text overlay provides an educational warning: **"Unauthorized communication with external organizations can be risky."** The accompanying instruction is: **"Review your organization’s policies and only share files and data with authorized stakeholders."**

**Interactive UI Elements:**
The message concludes with three sections designed for user interaction and feedback:

1.  **Acknowledgment (a):** A primary action button labeled **"Mark as Read."**
2.  **Structured Feedback (b):** A prompt asking **"Do you know why you received this message?"** followed by two feedback buttons: **"Yes"** (with a thumbs-up icon) and **"No"** (with a thumbs-down icon).
3.  **Open Feedback (c):** A section titled **"Share feedback or questions with your admin"** containing a multi-line text input field and a **"Submit"** button.
